results.headline: How Fame Divided Bandmates in Love
results.summary_short: “The Swell Season,” about the Irish-Czech duo Glen Hansard and Marketa Irglova, is less a musical documentary than the story of a breakup.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Swell Season

results.headline: Promised Paradise, Then Sent to Hell
results.summary_short: In “Oranges and Sunshine” Emily Watson is a social worker who uncovers a terrible scheme involving British children.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Oranges and Sunshine

results.headline: Number Crunching at the Apocalypse
results.summary_short: “Margin Call,” directed and written by J. C. Chandor, does a great deal to humanize the culprits — and beneficiaries — of the 2008 financial crisis.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Margin Call

results.headline: An Electric Car Drives an Industry’s Change
results.summary_short: Chris Paine’s “Revenge of the Electric Car,” the follow-up to “Who Killed the Electric Car?,” is a slick, enjoyable valentine to a retooling industry.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Revenge of the Electric Car

results.headline: Blazing a Feminist, and Hall of Fame, Trail
results.summary_short: “The Mighty Macs” recounts how Cathy Rush turned the 1972 women’s basketball team at tiny Immaculata College into national champions, fighting stereotypes along the way.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Mighty Macs

results.headline: Putting a Face to a Familiar Voice
results.summary_short: “Being Elmo” tells the story of the single-minded pursuit of puppet excellence by Kevin Clash, the man behind a certain fuzzy red creature.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Being Elmo: A Puppeteer's Journey

results.headline: Unleashing Some Havoc After a Case of Cabin Fever
results.summary_short: “Paranormal Activity 3” jumps back to 1988, as the invisible demon Toby hangs out with sisters in their childhood.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Paranormal Activity 3

results.headline: Finding Solace, Oceans From Home
results.summary_short: Instead of focusing on life’s harshness in “Le Havre,” Aki Kaurismaki reminds us of its modest charms and fleeting beauties.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Le Havre

results.headline: Brothers and Champions
results.summary_short: Sebastian Dehnhardt has created a glowing documentary on the Ukrainian boxers Vitali and Wladimir Klitschko.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Klitschko

results.headline: A Teenager’s Hardships, at Home and School
results.summary_short: “Norman” is a modest drama about a boy who creates a persona at school to keep the sadness of his home life at bay.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Norman

results.headline: Live and Let Laugh: A Secret Agent Reloads
results.summary_short: “Johnny English Reborn,” Rowan Atkinson’s sequel to his first James Bond spoof, is funnier and has a stronger personality than its forerunner.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Johnny English Reborn

results.headline: Now, Get Along Boys, or You’ll Be Poor
results.summary_short: In “The Reunion,” directed by Mike Pavone, three very different brothers must become business partners if they want their inheritance.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Reunion

results.headline: Woman Escapes a Cult but Not Her Own Past
results.summary_short: In “Martha Marcy May Marlene,” the debut feature film by Sean Durkin, Elizabeth Olsen plays a character trying to negotiate incompatible versions of herself.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Martha Marcy May Marlene

results.headline: For These Men, Basketball Means Hope
results.summary_short: “Elevate” is Anne Buford’s moving documentary about Senegalese basketball players given a chance to play and receive an education in the United States.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Elevate

results.headline: Gadfly of the ’60s, Getting His Due
results.summary_short: “Paul Goodman Changed My Life” is Jonathan Lee’s documentary portrait of the ’60s poet, teacher and social critic, whose name was once a household word.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Paul Goodman Changed My Life

results.headline: The Kids Stay in the Picture (but Not the Director)
results.summary_short: In “You All Are Captains,” the Spanish-French director Oliver Laxe gets some Moroccan children involved in his work as actors and filmmakers.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of You Are All Captains

results.headline: A Priest and His Buddy on a Downstream Journey
results.summary_short: A lot of the fun in “The Catechism Cataclysm,” a horror-comic head trip from the writer-director Todd Rohal, comes in the form of silly, strange line deliveries.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Catechism Cataclysm

results.headline: One Big Happy Family (and Prisoner)
results.summary_short: The depravity in Lucky McKee’s film “The Woman,” about a family and its captive, caused people to walk out when it was shown at Sundance.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Woman

results.headline: A Beautiful Prisoner Lost in Almodóvar’s Labyrinth
results.summary_short: An obsessive plastic surgeon keeps a beautiful young woman imprisoned in his home in this hybrid of thriller, melodrama and horror film.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Skin I Live In

results.headline: Last Resort Remains an Oasis of Dreams
results.summary_short: “Bombay Beach,” a documentary about an abandoned California wonderland that still holds wonder for some of its residents.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bombay Beach
